review.title: A New Penta-valued Logic Based Knowledge Representation
review.abstract: In this paper a knowledge representation model are proposed, FP5, which combine the ideas from fuzzy sets and penta-valued logic. FP5 represents imprecise properties whose accomplished degree is undefined, contradictory or indeterminate for some objects. Basic operations of conjunction, disjunction and negation are introduced. Relations to other representation models like fuzzy sets, intuitionistic, paraconsistent and bipolar fuzzy sets are discussed.
histories: The 12th International Conference Information Processing and Management of Uncertainty in Knowledge-Based Systems, June 22-27, 2008, Malaga, Spain
review.COMMENTS: The 12th International Conference Information Processing and Management of Uncertainty in Knowledge-Based Systems, June 22-27, 2008, Malaga, Spain

metadata.title: A New Penta-valued Logic Based Knowledge Representation

sections.text: This paper proposes a knowledge representation model, FP5, which combines the ideas of fuzzy sets and penta-rated logic. FP5 represents imprecise properties, the completed degree of which for some objects is undefined, contradictory or indefinite. Basic operations of conjunction, disjunction and negation are introduced. Relationships to other representation models such as fuzzy sets, intuitionist, paraconsistent and bipolar fuzzy sets are discussed. Keywords: fuzzy set, multi-rated logic, frank t norm, contradiction, uncertainty, indeterminacy, intuitionist fuzzy sets.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Fuzzy sets are a particularly well-suited tool to represent inaccurate concepts with poorly defined logical boundaries. If a property P is inaccurate, its negation P is considered inaccurate. Fuzzy set theory assumes that P and P are related, namely:) (1) (xPxP). However, this is not always true in real life. Therefore, P and P are sometimes represented independently of each other. On the other hand, fuzzy sets do not allow consideration of the presence of objects whose degree of affiliation P is undefined. Three estimated logic can solve the problem by allowing three logical values: true, false, and undefined. However, this is not always sufficient, and we can find contradictions when confirming a certain value x P and P at the same time. Fourthly evaluated logic can solve the problem because it uses four logical values: true, false, undefined, and contradictory. There is a rejection P for some values of x. In this situation, we can represent the knowledge defined on the basis of a defined penta-logical basis, unlogic-accurately defined.

sections.heading: 4 Penta-valued logic based on contradiction, undefinedness and indeterminacy
sections.text: Within the framework of this logic, we consider the following five logical points: true, false f, undefined u, contradictory c, and indeterminate i. Tables 1, 2, and 3 show tables for basic operators in this logic. One can see that the indeterminacy i is absorbed for the uncertainty u and the contradiction c.their negations.

sections.heading: 6 Fuzzy Set and Its Extension as FP5
sections.text: Imprecise concepts represented by bipolar fuzzy sets can be translated into FP5. Specific forms of bipolar fuzzy sets can also be translated into FP5, such as fuzzy sets, intuitionist fuzzy sets, and para-consistent fuzzy sets. Operations defined in (5.3), (5.4), and (5.5 provide new algebraic structures for the set types mentioned above.

sections.heading: 6.4 Paraconsistent Fuzzy Set as FP5
sections.text: We look at the para-consistent fuzzy setPFSA, defined by Membership FunctionA and Non-Membership Function A. We will translate it into a Penta-rated fuzzy set using formulas (6.1.1), thus defining the indices of truth, falsehood, contradiction and indeterminacy. sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: The method presented is based on some of the characteristics of the Frank t norms and a new logic based on five logical values: true, false, undefined, contradictory and indefinite. With this new logic new representations for fuzzy set, intuitionist fuzzy set, paraconsistent fuzzy set and bipolar fuzzy set were obtained. These new representations and the operators defined at FP5 provide new algebraic structures for these fuzzy set types.
